commit_message:
Update TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/yoga

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/yoga branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: Ibac36ae61cc94d3abae3df881e9adcc8fae1dac1

subject: Make --osd-spec and --crush-hierarchy not mutually exclusive
revisions:
[{'number': 2, 'created': '2022-03-10 18:16:59.000000000', 'files': ['tripleoclient/v2/overcloud_ceph.py'], 'message': "Make --osd-spec and --crush-hierarchy not mutually exclusive

Allow 'openstack overcloud ceph deploy' to take both the
--osd-spec and --crush-hierarchy arguments by removing
--crush-hierarchy from the mutually exclusive spec_group
and adding it to the regular parser.

Also, do not use mutually exclusive spec_group for 'openstack
overcloud ceph spec' since the --ceph-spec optsion is never
passed to 'openstack overcloud ceph spec'.

Conflict tripleoclient/v2/overcloud_ceph.py
OvercloudCephSpec class is not in wallaby so only OvercloudCephDeploy
class was modified.

Closes-Bug: 1964033
Change-Id: I88ed9e4f65ba0adfefd5e84111e4f787f77c5b97
(cherry picked from commit 88864174e801cb2dc5df7ac9b74df033a1efab6f)
"}]
commit_message:
Make --osd-spec and --crush-hierarchy not mutually exclusive

Allow 'openstack overcloud ceph deploy' to take both the
--osd-spec and --crush-hierarchy arguments by removing
--crush-hierarchy from the mutually exclusive spec_group
and adding it to the regular parser.

Also, do not use mutually exclusive spec_group for 'openstack
overcloud ceph spec' since the --ceph-spec optsion is never
passed to 'openstack overcloud ceph spec'.

Conflict tripleoclient/v2/overcloud_ceph.py
OvercloudCephSpec class is not in wallaby so only OvercloudCephDeploy
class was modified.

Closes-Bug: 1964033
Change-Id: I88ed9e4f65ba0adfefd5e84111e4f787f77c5b97
(cherry picked from commit 88864174e801cb2dc5df7ac9b74df033a1efab6f)

commit_message:
Add job separation for the new tests

This change adds a new playbook to exercise new SDK compabilt modules.
At this time the new playbook is empty and the test has been made
voding, in a follow-on review the role inclusions will be filled out to
ensure we're covering and showing valid test results for all converted
modules supported by this collection.

Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kecarter@redhat.com>
Change-Id: Idd112760174df40d22275fe5336799763716e344

commit_message:
FT of multi tenants for CNF

This patch adds functional test cases to validate instantiate CNF
functionality in a multi-tenant environment.
Validates CNF instantiation is only allowed when CNF and VIM
belongs to same tenant.

Implements: blueprint k8s-namespace

commit_message:
Use utf-16-le if BOM not present

In case no BOM is present in the CSV file the utf-16 codec won't work.
We fail over to utf-16-le as Little Endian is commonly used.

Change-Id: I3e25ce4997f5dd3df87caba753daced65838f85a
(cherry picked from commit 697fa6f3b6db10408eaadd57450456de87f13519)

commit_message:
Add all jobs from the periodic queue to experimental one

It may help with e.g. debugging periodic jobs as in experimental
queue they can be triggered manually on any specific patch.
It also will not hurt us too much as experimental pipeline isn't
run automatically anywhere.

Change-Id: If4b8f6bb8195ae6e7db1be5ec88d83bf131adf3b

subject: fix: Fix the log_dir
revisions:
[{'number': 2, 'created': '2022-03-14 02:22:37.000000000', 'files': ['etc/gunicorn.py', '.zuul.yaml', 'container/Dockerfile', 'devstack/settings', 'libs/skyline-nginx/skyline_nginx/templates/nginx.conf.j2'], 'message': 'fix: Fix the log_dir

If the log_dir is /var/log/kolla, and when we
deploy with devstack, we only chown the permission
for /var/log/kolla/skyline with stack user.
But the permission for /var/log/kolla is still root.
So it can not be access by stack user.
We will both change the log_dir in skyline-console
project.

Change-Id: I852c44cda2f9879aa8d8e405bb39bba13f35b8ca
'}]
commit_message:
fix: Fix the log_dir

If the log_dir is /var/log/kolla, and when we
deploy with devstack, we only chown the permission
for /var/log/kolla/skyline with stack user.
But the permission for /var/log/kolla is still root.
So it can not be access by stack user.
We will both change the log_dir in skyline-console
project.

Change-Id: I852c44cda2f9879aa8d8e405bb39bba13f35b8ca

commit_message:
Add documents for enhance operations in V2

This patch provides Tacker documents for enhance operations(heal,
scale, update, changeextconn) in V2-API. The specification about new
API is added to API Reference. Also, update operation is added to
Tacker Use Cases Guide and CLI Reference.

This patch also includes changes to the user data script.

Implements: blueprint support-nfv-solv3-change-external-connectivity
Implements: blueprint support-nfv-solv3-heal-vnf
Implements: blueprint support-nfv-solv3-modify-vnf
Implements: blueprint support-nfv-solv3-scale-vnf
Change-Id: I6adefc59903a4c8305a66c224c086af4b86812df

commit_message:
Remove questionable defaults from the network configuration

We definitely should not default to using Google DNS or assuming a
specific MTU. The default gateway won't work for many deployments.

Remove them, refactor network_metadata and add some unit tests.

Change-Id: Icb5d077a5f68b5affc1ed545e04c96dcc01d9f3e

commit_message:
Fix permissions on ganesha related tasks

This patch just adds 'become: true' in several ganesha related tasks.
The fixed tasks are supposed to create and distribute config files (and
make operations on that portion of the fs now owned by the stack user),
 hence we need to fix a few permissions issues.

Closes-Bug: #1963285
Change-Id: Ia5a763be5710c9083cfae30b8fd3f698c65846a1
(cherry picked from commit fefd39a26ce02c500f9bad368c59917757453480)

The cephadm container image tag is usually alphanumeric (e.g. it can

commit_message:
Cast tripleo_cephadm_container_tag to string

The cephadm container image tag is usually alphanumeric (e.g. it can
be found in the form of <major>-<minor> or something like that).
For this reason we need jinja to produce the right string that should
be passed to the --image option and avoid an unexpected templating
error where the tripleo_cephadm_container_tag must be str and not int.

Change-Id: Ibaf94f72d3532ebac580cca96f71ad8d25ff2eff
(cherry picked from commit 8bab831a8a1c543adc1cc99d2a28135590ac0551)

subject: libvirt: support SASL authentication
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2022-03-12 16:59:00.000000000', 'files': ['ansible/roles/nova-cell/defaults/main.yml', 'ansible/roles/nova-cell/templates/sasl.conf.j2', 'doc/source/reference/compute/libvirt-guide.rst', 'etc/kolla/passwords.yml', 'ansible/roles/nova-cell/templates/nova-compute.json.j2', 'ansible/roles/nova-cell/handlers/main.yml', 'ansible/roles/nova-cell/templates/nova-libvirt.json.j2', 'ansible/roles/nova-cell/templates/auth.conf.j2', 'ansible/roles/nova-cell/templates/libvirtd.conf.j2', 'ansible/roles/nova-cell/tasks/config.yml', 'releasenotes/notes/libvirt-sasl-404199143610fb75.yaml'], 'message': 'libvirt: support SASL authentication

In Kolla Ansible OpenStack deployments, by default, libvirt is
configured to allow read-write access via an unauthenticated,
unencrypted TCP connection, using the internal API network.  This is to
facilitate migration between hosts.

By default, Kolla Ansible does not use encryption for services on the
internal network (and did not support it until Ussuri). However, most
other services on the internal network are at least authenticated
(usually via passwords), ensuring that they cannot be used by anyone
with access to the network, unless they have credentials.

The main issue here is the lack of authentication. Any client with
access to the internal network is able to connect to the libvirt TCP
port and make arbitrary changes to the hypervisor. This could include
starting a VM, modifying an existing VM, etc. Given the flexibility of
the domain options, it could be seen as equivalent to having root access
to the hypervisor.

Kolla Ansible supports libvirt TLS [1] since the Train release, using
client and server certificates for mutual authentication and encryption.
However, this feature is not enabled by default, and requires
certificates to be generated for each compute host.

This change adds support for libvirt SASL authentication, and enables it
by default. This provides base level of security. Deployments requiring
further security should use libvirt TLS.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/kolla-ansible/latest/reference/compute/libvirt-guide.html#libvirt-tls

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/kolla/+/833021
Closes-Bug: #1964013
Change-Id: Ia91ceeb609e4cdb144433122b443028c0278b71e
(cherry picked from commit d2d4b53d47df3b1a250c21404a8ec140873d4ce5)
'}]
commit_message:
libvirt: support SASL authentication

In Kolla Ansible OpenStack deployments, by default, libvirt is
configured to allow read-write access via an unauthenticated,
unencrypted TCP connection, using the internal API network.  This is to
facilitate migration between hosts.

By default, Kolla Ansible does not use encryption for services on the
internal network (and did not support it until Ussuri). However, most
other services on the internal network are at least authenticated
(usually via passwords), ensuring that they cannot be used by anyone
with access to the network, unless they have credentials.

The main issue here is the lack of authentication. Any client with
access to the internal network is able to connect to the libvirt TCP
port and make arbitrary changes to the hypervisor. This could include
starting a VM, modifying an existing VM, etc. Given the flexibility of
the domain options, it could be seen as equivalent to having root access
to the hypervisor.

Kolla Ansible supports libvirt TLS [1] since the Train release, using
client and server certificates for mutual authentication and encryption.
However, this feature is not enabled by default, and requires
certificates to be generated for each compute host.

This change adds support for libvirt SASL authentication, and enables it
by default. This provides base level of security. Deployments requiring
further security should use libvirt TLS.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/kolla-ansible/latest/reference/compute/libvirt-guide.html#libvirt-tls

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/kolla/+/833021
Closes-Bug: #1964013
Change-Id: Ia91ceeb609e4cdb144433122b443028c0278b71e
(cherry picked from commit d2d4b53d47df3b1a250c21404a8ec140873d4ce5)

commit_message:
Add amphorav2 provider driver options

The amphorav2 provider driver [1] was introduced in Ussuri release as
experimental. Documentation on how to configure is available in [2].

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/q/topic:jobboard

subject: Do not remount failed drives
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2019-04-02 10:39:06.000000000', 'files': ['manifests/storage/mount.pp', 'facts.d/swift_fstab_dev_list.sh'], 'message': "Do not remount failed drives

When a drive fails, swift umount it, and comments out the entry in
/etc/fstab. When puppet runs again, it re-adds a *NEW* entry in
fstab and attempts to remount the drive.

With this patch, a fact swift_fstab_dev_list.sh tells if an entry
exists but is commented-out, and if that's the case, then mount.pp
doesn't attempt to mount the disk again.

Change-Id: I5a4b40401790498742cf0cdcee473a78a9f28d2b
"}]
commit_message:
Do not remount failed drives

When a drive fails, swift umount it, and comments out the entry in
/etc/fstab. When puppet runs again, it re-adds a *NEW* entry in
fstab and attempts to remount the drive.

With this patch, a fact swift_fstab_dev_list.sh tells if an entry
exists but is commented-out, and if that's the case, then mount.pp
doesn't attempt to mount the disk again.

Change-Id: I5a4b40401790498742cf0cdcee473a78a9f28d2b

subject: Mount Swift disk even if not formatted by puppet-swift
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3153, 'name': 'Emilien Macchi', 'email': 'emilien@redhat.com', 'username': 'emilienm'}, {'_account_id': 6968, 'name': 'Christian Schwede', 'email': 'cschwede@redhat.com', 'username': 'cschwede'}, {'_account_id': 8871, 'name': 'Elastic Recheck', 'username': 'elasticrecheck'}, {'_account_id': 8971, 'name': 'Fuel CI', 'username': 'fuel-ci', 'inactive': True, 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 14985, 'name': 'Alex Schultz', 'email': 'aschultz@next-development.com', 'username': 'mwhahaha'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
revisions:
[{'number': 2, 'created': '2018-02-19 15:34:52.000000000', 'files': ['manifests/storage/xfs.pp', 'releasenotes/notes/swift-always-mount-xfs-e5cceee5b6b50074.yaml'], 'message': 'Mount Swift disk even if not formatted by puppet-swift

Currently a given Swift disk will only be mounted if it was formatted
first with XFS by puppet-swift. However, if there is an existing XFS FS
it will not be mounted, which might create other issues afterwards.

There are multiple possibilites for an existing XFS filesystem, one
being to use existing Swift disks and the data that is already stored.

This patch only changes the chaining arrow from notifying to ordering,
and therefore always tries to mount the given disk.

Closes-Bug: 1717021
Change-Id: I7693a21b6b32fcaf4dc9efe32cd9f1c38ebffa7c
'}]
commit_message:
Mount Swift disk even if not formatted by puppet-swift

Currently a given Swift disk will only be mounted if it was formatted
first with XFS by puppet-swift. However, if there is an existing XFS FS
it will not be mounted, which might create other issues afterwards.

There are multiple possibilites for an existing XFS filesystem, one
being to use existing Swift disks and the data that is already stored.

This patch only changes the chaining arrow from notifying to ordering,
and therefore always tries to mount the given disk.

Closes-Bug: 1717021
Change-Id: I7693a21b6b32fcaf4dc9efe32cd9f1c38ebffa7c

commit_message:
Update VPP ML2 and Agent parameters

The latest release of networking-vpp ML2 drvier/agent requires the
following addtional configs:
- For ML2 driver, we need to configure L3 vpp-routing hosts
- For VPP agent, we need to configure type_drivers and serivce_plugins

Closes-Bug: #1790526

Change-Id: I0a19abcc59e294ee54380c08c552ee1b147c837a
Signed-off-by: Feng Pan <fpan@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Introduce heat::clients class

This patch aims to manage OpenStack services clients
configuration in Heat which including:
 - Aodh
 - Barbican
 - Cinder
 - Glance
 - Magnum
 - Neutron
 - Nova

Change-Id: I07993df9993ad3e69848b915cd659b46322b75cf

subject: Deprecate usage of authtoken parameters in providers
revisions:
[{'number': 2, 'created': '2022-02-21 14:58:41.000000000', 'files': ['lib/puppet/provider/neutron.rb', 'releasenotes/notes/provider-deprecate-at-params-d688fca46bafe562.yaml'], 'message': 'Deprecate usage of authtoken parameters in providers

When SRBAC is completely implemented according to the current spec,
each service user no longer has full admin privilege but has access
limited to the actual requirement. This means that we are no longer
able to use service users to create resources.

This change is a prep-work to get rid of usage of the service user,
currently loaded from authtoken parameters in the .conf file. Now
each providers loads clouds.yaml file placed in /etc/openstack/puppet.

Depends-on: https://review.opendev.org/806474

Change-Id: I55436944a6cdeca7786cd07580d21643094d2d8e

commit_message:
Deprecate usage of authtoken parameters in providers

When SRBAC is completely implemented according to the current spec,
each service user no longer has full admin privilege but has access
limited to the actual requirement. This means that we are no longer
able to use service users to create resources.

This change is a prep-work to get rid of usage of the service user,
currently loaded from authtoken parameters in the .conf file. Now
each providers loads clouds.yaml file placed in /etc/openstack/puppet.

Depends-on: https://review.opendev.org/806474
Depends-on: https://review.opendev.org/828025
Change-Id: I55436944a6cdeca7786cd07580d21643094d2d8e

commit_message:
Drop support for old libvirt package

This change removes logic to support very old packages. Currently all
distros we support provider puppet 5.6 or later and we don't expect
users are using packages older than distro packages.

Change-Id: I8af9b282e88e479bcc42f7756bf9537fada837be

commit_message:
ceph_spec_bootstrap should not always require a method

Method from I17f4303636b08d2be2d0f6e248242ad53c5fddf1
should not be required input. It was meant only to
disambiguate if >1 methods were used. If only one
method is passed, then ceph_spec_bootstrap should
be able to figure out which method to use.

Related-Bug: 1964524
Closes-Bug: 1964530
Change-Id: I7d9ae9328566c792d57c7ad95215a0aaabed4f6b

subject: libvirt: support SASL authentication
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2022-03-12 17:00:29.000000000', 'files': ['ansible/roles/nova-cell/defaults/main.yml', 'ansible/roles/nova-cell/templates/sasl.conf.j2', 'doc/source/reference/compute/libvirt-guide.rst', 'etc/kolla/passwords.yml', 'ansible/roles/nova-cell/templates/nova-compute.json.j2', 'ansible/roles/nova-cell/handlers/main.yml', 'ansible/roles/nova-cell/templates/nova-libvirt.json.j2', 'ansible/roles/nova-cell/templates/auth.conf.j2', 'ansible/roles/nova-cell/templates/libvirtd.conf.j2', 'ansible/roles/nova-cell/tasks/config.yml', 'releasenotes/notes/libvirt-sasl-404199143610fb75.yaml'], 'message': 'libvirt: support SASL authentication

In Kolla Ansible OpenStack deployments, by default, libvirt is
configured to allow read-write access via an unauthenticated,
unencrypted TCP connection, using the internal API network.  This is to
facilitate migration between hosts.

By default, Kolla Ansible does not use encryption for services on the
internal network (and did not support it until Ussuri). However, most
other services on the internal network are at least authenticated
(usually via passwords), ensuring that they cannot be used by anyone
with access to the network, unless they have credentials.

The main issue here is the lack of authentication. Any client with
access to the internal network is able to connect to the libvirt TCP
port and make arbitrary changes to the hypervisor. This could include
starting a VM, modifying an existing VM, etc. Given the flexibility of
the domain options, it could be seen as equivalent to having root access
to the hypervisor.

Kolla Ansible supports libvirt TLS [1] since the Train release, using
client and server certificates for mutual authentication and encryption.
However, this feature is not enabled by default, and requires
certificates to be generated for each compute host.

This change adds support for libvirt SASL authentication, and enables it
by default. This provides base level of security. Deployments requiring
further security should use libvirt TLS.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/kolla-ansible/latest/reference/compute/libvirt-guide.html#libvirt-tls

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/kolla/+/833021
Closes-Bug: #1964013
Change-Id: Ia91ceeb609e4cdb144433122b443028c0278b71e
(cherry picked from commit d2d4b53d47df3b1a250c21404a8ec140873d4ce5)
'}]
commit_message:
libvirt: support SASL authentication

In Kolla Ansible OpenStack deployments, by default, libvirt is
configured to allow read-write access via an unauthenticated,
unencrypted TCP connection, using the internal API network.  This is to
facilitate migration between hosts.

By default, Kolla Ansible does not use encryption for services on the
internal network (and did not support it until Ussuri). However, most
other services on the internal network are at least authenticated
(usually via passwords), ensuring that they cannot be used by anyone
with access to the network, unless they have credentials.

The main issue here is the lack of authentication. Any client with
access to the internal network is able to connect to the libvirt TCP
port and make arbitrary changes to the hypervisor. This could include
starting a VM, modifying an existing VM, etc. Given the flexibility of
the domain options, it could be seen as equivalent to having root access
to the hypervisor.

Kolla Ansible supports libvirt TLS [1] since the Train release, using
client and server certificates for mutual authentication and encryption.
However, this feature is not enabled by default, and requires
certificates to be generated for each compute host.

This change adds support for libvirt SASL authentication, and enables it
by default. This provides base level of security. Deployments requiring
further security should use libvirt TLS.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/kolla-ansible/latest/reference/compute/libvirt-guide.html#libvirt-tls

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/kolla/+/833021
Closes-Bug: #1964013
Change-Id: Ia91ceeb609e4cdb144433122b443028c0278b71e
(cherry picked from commit d2d4b53d47df3b1a250c21404a8ec140873d4ce5)

subject: libvirt: support SASL authentication
revisions:

commit_message:
libvirt: support SASL authentication

In Kolla Ansible OpenStack deployments, by default, libvirt is
configured to allow read-write access via an unauthenticated,
unencrypted TCP connection, using the internal API network.  This is to
facilitate migration between hosts.

By default, Kolla Ansible does not use encryption for services on the
internal network (and did not support it until Ussuri). However, most
other services on the internal network are at least authenticated
(usually via passwords), ensuring that they cannot be used by anyone
with access to the network, unless they have credentials.

The main issue here is the lack of authentication. Any client with
access to the internal network is able to connect to the libvirt TCP
port and make arbitrary changes to the hypervisor. This could include
starting a VM, modifying an existing VM, etc. Given the flexibility of
the domain options, it could be seen as equivalent to having root access
to the hypervisor.

Kolla Ansible supports libvirt TLS [1] since the Train release, using
client and server certificates for mutual authentication and encryption.
However, this feature is not enabled by default, and requires
certificates to be generated for each compute host.

This change adds support for libvirt SASL authentication, and enables it
by default. This provides base level of security. Deployments requiring
further security should use libvirt TLS.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/kolla-ansible/latest/reference/compute/libvirt-guide.html#libvirt-tls

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/kolla/+/833021
Closes-Bug: #1964013
Change-Id: Ia91ceeb609e4cdb144433122b443028c0278b71e
(cherry picked from commit d2d4b53d47df3b1a250c21404a8ec140873d4ce5)

commit_message:
Address RemovedInDjango40Warning (7)

HttpRequest.is_ajax() was marked as deprecated since Django 3.1 and will be
removed in Django 4.0 [1].

While the current implementation of is_ajax() relies on a jQuery-specific way
of signifying AJAX as noted in the Django relnotes, horizon works with this.
Thus this commit copies the existing logic of HttpRequest.is_ajax() to the
horizon repo (as horizon.utils.http.is_ajax()) and consumes it.

https: //docs.djangoproject.com/en/4.0/releases/3.1/#features-deprecated-in-3-1
Change-Id: I3def53033524985818a891a1b9d4659fad4ba2ba

commit_message:
libvirt: support SASL authentication

In Kolla Ansible OpenStack deployments, by default, libvirt is
configured to allow read-write access via an unauthenticated,
unencrypted TCP connection, using the internal API network.  This is to
facilitate migration between hosts.

By default, Kolla Ansible does not use encryption for services on the
internal network (and did not support it until Ussuri). However, most
other services on the internal network are at least authenticated
(usually via passwords), ensuring that they cannot be used by anyone
with access to the network, unless they have credentials.

The main issue here is the lack of authentication. Any client with
access to the internal network is able to connect to the libvirt TCP
port and make arbitrary changes to the hypervisor. This could include
starting a VM, modifying an existing VM, etc. Given the flexibility of
the domain options, it could be seen as equivalent to having root access
to the hypervisor.

Kolla Ansible supports libvirt TLS [1] since the Train release, using
client and server certificates for mutual authentication and encryption.
However, this feature is not enabled by default, and requires
certificates to be generated for each compute host.

This change adds support for libvirt SASL authentication, and enables it
by default. This provides base level of security. Deployments requiring
further security should use libvirt TLS.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/kolla-ansible/latest/reference/compute/libvirt-guide.html#libvirt-tls

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/kolla/+/833021
Closes-Bug: #1964013
Change-Id: Ia91ceeb609e4cdb144433122b443028c0278b71e

revisions:
[{'number': 4, 'created': '2022-02-21 14:54:21.000000000', 'files': ['lib/puppet/provider/cinder.rb', 'releasenotes/notes/provider-deprecate-at-params-65e1ed50038822d3.yaml'], 'message': 'Deprecate usage of authtoken parameters in providers

When SRBAC is completely implemented according to the current spec,
each service user no longer has full admin privilege but has access
limited to the actual requirement. This means that we are no longer
able to use service users to create resources.

This change is a prep-work to get rid of usage of the service user,
currently loaded from authtoken parameters in the .conf file. Now
each providers loads clouds.yaml file placed in /etc/openstack/puppet.

Depends-on: https://review.opendev.org/806474
Depends-on: https://review.opendev.org/828025
Change-Id: I80ea9fc1da31696cafa77ff12febfd4054f435bc
'}]
commit_message:
Deprecate usage of authtoken parameters in providers

When SRBAC is completely implemented according to the current spec,
each service user no longer has full admin privilege but has access
limited to the actual requirement. This means that we are no longer
able to use service users to create resources.

This change is a prep-work to get rid of usage of the service user,
currently loaded from authtoken parameters in the .conf file. Now
each providers loads clouds.yaml file placed in /etc/openstack/puppet.

Depends-on: https://review.opendev.org/806474
Depends-on: https://review.opendev.org/828025
Change-Id: I80ea9fc1da31696cafa77ff12febfd4054f435bc

subject: Fix default of vswitch::provider in RedHat OS
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2022-02-27 13:47:00.000000000', 'files': ['manifests/params.pp'], 'message': "Fix default of vswitch::provider in RedHat OS

The vswitch::provider parameter is set to 'ovs_redhat' but it results
in including the vwitch::ovs_redhat class which has never existed.
The parameter is supposed to take ovs or dpdk thus the default should
be ovs even in RedHat OS.

Change-Id: I84d023ab82c0432eeb762682d0496d6c6bbf2e82
(cherry picked from commit 961eed828cdc4fb78b28a13fd6b3fbdbfdca474f)
"}]
commit_message:
Fix default of vswitch::provider in RedHat OS

The vswitch::provider parameter is set to 'ovs_redhat' but it results
in including the vwitch::ovs_redhat class which has never existed.
The parameter is supposed to take ovs or dpdk thus the default should
be ovs even in RedHat OS.

Change-Id: I84d023ab82c0432eeb762682d0496d6c6bbf2e82
(cherry picked from commit 961eed828cdc4fb78b28a13fd6b3fbdbfdca474f)

commit_message:
Clean duplicated QoS bandwidth related methods in ovs_lib module

This patch also some helper methods used in the
minimum bandwidth qos methods as it seems that we had things almost
duplicated in methods like _find/update/delete_{qos,queue} and
find/update/delete_{qos,queue}.

It also moves functional tests for the ingress bandwidth limit rules
methods to more appropriate module.

Related-bug: 1959567
Change-Id: I848af01c8fe3a08b26d05e37d225c944ea080f03

commit_message:
Update TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/yoga

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/yoga branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: Iaa017186825c851e7e96c1832e2e55037c4a06e4

subject: Check whether vxlan group and local addresses are IPv4 or IPv6
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2022-03-11 12:17:48.000000000', 'files': ['neutron/tests/functional/agent/linux/test_ip_lib.py', 'neutron/agent/linux/ip_lib.py', 'neutron/tests/unit/agent/linux/test_ip_lib.py'], 'message': "Check whether vxlan group and local addresses are IPv4 or IPv6

Check if group and/or local addresses passed to ip_lib / add_vxlan()
are IPv4 or IPv6. In case of IPv4 fill 'vxlan_group' and 'vxlan_local'
arguments and in case of IPv6 fill 'vxlan_group6' and 'vxlan_local6'
arguments to be passed down to privileged create_interface() method.
In case of an invalid address format raise an AddrFormatError exception.

Closes-Bug: #1952897
Change-Id: I2e3b0c1635627edb2c86c6120b0410ab3c4678b2
(cherry picked from commit a47e9494c1d8895425ad3a05a2c2290c74f0b647)
"}]
commit_message:
Check whether vxlan group and local addresses are IPv4 or IPv6

Check if group and/or local addresses passed to ip_lib / add_vxlan()
are IPv4 or IPv6. In case of IPv4 fill 'vxlan_group' and 'vxlan_local'
arguments and in case of IPv6 fill 'vxlan_group6' and 'vxlan_local6'
arguments to be passed down to privileged create_interface() method.
In case of an invalid address format raise an AddrFormatError exception.

Closes-Bug: #1952897
Change-Id: I2e3b0c1635627edb2c86c6120b0410ab3c4678b2
(cherry picked from commit a47e9494c1d8895425ad3a05a2c2290c74f0b647)

commit_message:
Use tox 3.1.1 fixes

By 3.1.1, tox had fixed:

- [1] which mishandled the basepython directive.
- ignoring PYTHONDONTWRITEBYTECODE [2]

Require this version and remove the workarounds.

See ML thread [3] for some details

[1] https://github.com/tox-dev/tox/issues/477
[2] https://github.com/tox-dev/tox/commit/336f4f6bd8b53223f940fc5cfc43b1bbd78d4699
[3] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-July/thread.html#132075

Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>
Change-Id: Idcb204a0dcda92f2bd8cbae37d510d5993c739fe
(cherry picked from commit c409caae792eb7024b212c52d63eda8b8f383be9)

subject: db: Increase timeout for migration tests
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2022-03-08 21:32:40.000000000', 'files': ['cinder/tests/unit/db/test_migrations.py'], 'message': "db: Increase timeout for migration tests

We're seeing quite a few timeout failures on the following tests in
'cinder.tests.unit.db.test_migrations':

- TestModelsSyncMySQL.test_models_sync
- TestMigrationsWalkMySQL.test_walk_versions

Currently, this is mainly affecting the AArch64 CI but as we saw in
nova, it's possible for this to have an impact on other underpowered CI
hosts. Like nova change I82b9a064d77251945ff1ae99d7049f367ddde92e, we
now set 'TIMEOUT_SCALING_FACTOR' for these tests to 4, meaning these
tests will now get 240 seconds (or 4 minutes) to execute (we set
OS_TEST_TIMEOUT to 60 in 'tox.ini'). As discussed in that change, there
are other ways we could address this but this seems the most sensible
approach to take.

Change-Id: Iaab4984ed5d4cc8d02ef934a0c6f5980a0fb4687
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>
"}]
commit_message:
db: Increase timeout for migration tests

We're seeing quite a few timeout failures on the following tests in
'cinder.tests.unit.db.test_migrations':

- TestModelsSyncMySQL.test_models_sync
- TestMigrationsWalkMySQL.test_walk_versions

Currently, this is mainly affecting the AArch64 CI but as we saw in
nova, it's possible for this to have an impact on other underpowered CI
hosts. Like nova change I82b9a064d77251945ff1ae99d7049f367ddde92e, we
now set 'TIMEOUT_SCALING_FACTOR' for these tests to 4, meaning these
tests will now get 240 seconds (or 4 minutes) to execute (we set
OS_TEST_TIMEOUT to 60 in 'tox.ini'). As discussed in that change, there
are other ways we could address this but this seems the most sensible
approach to take.

Change-Id: Iaab4984ed5d4cc8d02ef934a0c6f5980a0fb4687
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>
